facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 28, 1957, of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision No. 78 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 28, 1957, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Criminal Revision No. 78 of 1957, arising out of the judgment and order dated August 21, 1957, of the Court of Special Judge at Gwalior in File No. 2/57 Special Case.

facts.text: High Court directed Special Judge, Indore, to order Deputy Superintendent of Police to carry on investigation afresh.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the, Judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur directing the Special Judge, Indore, to order the Deputy Superintendent of Police to carry on the investigation afresh.

facts.text: Shri Mohinder Nath Bhalla was manager of Daisy Sewing Machine Co. Ltd., Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are simple. One Shri Mohinder Nath Bhalla was the manager of Daisy Sewing Machine Co. Ltd., Bhopal.

facts.text: On January 11, 1955, between 12 and 1 p.m., Shri Bhalla contacted Sub-Inspector of Police, Special Police Establishment, Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: On January 11, 1955, between 12 and 1 p. m., he companytacted the Sub-Inspector of Police, Special Police Establishment, Gwalior, and gave him the following information

facts.text: Company had stall in Gwalior Mela; Shri Bhalla needed to book 20 empty wooden cases (12 big, 8 small) to New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany had opened their stall in the Gwalior Mela and he  Shri Bhalla  had to book empty wooden cases of machine and machine parts from Gwalior Mela, to Now Delhi.

facts.text: Station Master demanded 10 annas per case as illegal gratification; Shri Bhalla refused.

anchor.surface_text: When lie went to the station to enquire for booking the said cases, the Station Master demanded annas ten for each case as illegal gratification, but he did number agree to it.

facts.text: Assistant Station Master agreed to accept 8 annas per case and asked to bring cases between 2-4 p.m. on January 11, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the Assistant Station Master agreed to accept annas eight for each case and asked him to bring the wooden cases between 2 and 4 p. m. on the same day, i.e., January 11, 1955.

facts.text: Police laid trap with marked rupee notes given to Shri Bhalla.

anchor.surface_text: The numbers of the rupee numberes intended to be given as bribe to the Assistant Station Master were entered in a memorandum which was attested by witnesses. The said rupee numberes were given to Shri Bhalla in the presence of the witnesses.

facts.text: Assistant Station Master took the bribe after bargaining.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Station Master, after some bargaining, took the bribe,

facts.text: Shri Bhalla gave prearranged signal after bribery; Sub-Inspector arrested and recovered marked notes from Assistant Station Master Shri Mubarak Ali.

anchor.surface_text: and after the act of bribery was companypleted, Shri Bhalla gave the prearranged signal. The Sub-Inspector then went to the Station Office and disclosed his identity to the Assistant Station Master in the presence of witnesses and asked him to produce the money taken by him as bribe.

facts.text: Numbers on recovered notes tallied with memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: The numbers on those numberes tallied with those numbered in the memorandum.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector concluded offences under ss. 120B, 161 IPC and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act by Shri Mubarak Ali and Shri Mool Chand.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector, having regard to the aforesaid facts, came to the companyclusion that the facts disclosed offences punishable under ss. 120-B and 161 of the Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  2 of 1947 , had been companymitted by the Assistant Station Master, Shri Mubarak Ali, and the pointsman, Shri Mool Chand,

facts.text: Sub-Inspector sent report to Special Police Establishment Office on January 11, 1955; registered on January 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day he sent a report of the aforesaid facts to the Special Police Establishment Office, Madhya Bharat. The office registered it on January 14, 1955, in its register.

facts.text: On January 21, 1955, Sub-Inspector filed application for permission to investigate before Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: Seven days thereafter, on January 21, 1955, the Sub- Inspector filed an application before the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Gwalior, asking for permission to investigate the offence under the aforesaid sections.

facts.text: Charge-sheet filed on October 1, 1955, before Special Judge, Anti-Corruption, Indore.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1955, a charge-sheet was filed before the Special Judge, Anti-Corruption, Indore.

facts.text: Respondent filed objections questioning validity of Additional District Magistrate's permission order.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the record that soon after the case was taken up for trial, the respondent filed objections questioning, inter alia, the validity of the order of the Additional District Magistrate giving permission to the Sub-Inspector to make the investigation.

facts.text: Special Judge on August 21, 1957, discharged Shri Mool Chand and charged Shri Mubarak Ali under s.161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On August 21, 1957, the learned Special Judge made an order discharging Shri Mool Chand, the pointsman, and charging Shri Mubarak Ali, the Assistant Station Master, under s. 161 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Special Judge disallowed accused's objection on permission, finding Magistrate satisfied himself prima facie.

anchor.surface_text: By the said order the learned Judge... disallowed the objection of the accused on the ground that on the date when the Magistrate gave the sanction, there were many papers in companynection with a case against the accused, on observing which the Magi- strate companyld have satisfied himself whether-there was a prima facie case or number against the accused

facts.text: High Court in revision held Sub-Inspector applied for permission ten days after investigation started and Magistrate gave routine permission.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that the Sub-Inspector applied for permission ten days after investigation had started and that the Magistrate did number satisfy himself that there were good and sufficient reasons for authorising the officer of a lower- rank to companyduct the investigation but had given the permission as a mere matter of routine.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal decided on February 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. February 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held provisions of s.5A not strictly complied with; Magistrate gave permission mechanically without material.

anchor.surface_text: Ex facie, it appears to us, just like it appeared to the High Court, that the Magistrate did number realise the significance of his order giving permission, but only mechanically issued the order on the basis of the application which did number disclose any reason,

facts.text: Investigation started on January 11, 1955, before permission on January 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: From the narration of facts given supra, it would be seen that in the present case Shri Bhalla gave information to the Sub-Inspector on January 11, 1955,...

facts.text: Sub-Inspector's application for permission stated he was deputed and sought permission under s.5A; Magistrate ordered 'permission given'.

anchor.surface_text: In that application the Sub-Inspector stated that he had been deputed to investigate the case and therefore permission might be given to him to do so under s. 5-A of the Act. On that application, the Magistrate passed the order permission given .

facts.text: No evidence adduced by prosecution to show Magistrate considered material before granting permission.

anchor.surface_text: though years have elapsed between the date of the petition and that of the order of the Sessions Judge, to adduce any evidence to support the companytention that the Magistrate gave the permission to the Sub-Inspector only after satisfying himself on the advisability of doing so on the material placed before him.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3  as it stood before the Prevention of Corruption  Amendment  Act, 1955  50 of 1955  An offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 or section 165A of the Indian Penal Code  Act 45 of 1860  shall be deemed to be a cognizable offence for the purposes of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898  Act 5 of 1898 , notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained therein

Section 4.  1  Where in any trial of an offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code  Act 45 of 1860 , it is proved that an accused person has accepted or obtained, or has agreed to accept or attempted to obtain, for himself or for any other person, any gratification  other than legal remuneration  or any valuable thing from any person, it shall be presumed unless the contrary is proved that he accepted or obtained, or agreed to accept or attempted to obtain, that gratification or that valuable thing, as the case may be, as a motive or reward such as is mentioned in the said section 161, or, as the case may be, without consideration or for a consideration which he knows to be inadequate .

concepts.unlisted_description: Presumption of corrupt motive from acceptance of gratification

concepts.interpretation: Requires previous sanction for cognizance; desirable to set out facts but not fatal if proved aliunde.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in holding that the Magistrate gave the permission as a mere matter of routine without satisfying himself as to the advisability of giving such permission

anchor.surface_text: (i) the High Court was not justified in holding that the Magistrate gave the permission as a mere matter of routine without satisfying himself as to the advisability of giving such permission

issues.text: Whether the High Court was wrong in holding that the investigation started ten days prior to the obtaining of permission of the Magistrate by the Sub-Inspector

anchor.surface_text: (ii) the High Court was wrong in holding that the investigation started ten days prior to the obtaining of permission of the Magistrate by the Sub-Inspector. holdings.text: The provisions of s. 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act have not been strictly complied with in this case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, without any hesitation, agree with the High Court that the provisions of s. 5A of the Act have not been strictly complied with in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application lacked reasons; magistrate's order mechanical ('permission given'); no evidence adduced by prosecution that magistrate considered material or exercised discretion; agrees with High Court findings.

holdings.text: Section 5A of the Act is mandatory and requires strict compliance by magistrate exercising discretion on relevant material before authorizing subordinate police officer to investigate.

anchor.surface_text: These statutory safeguards must be strictly complied with, for they were conceived in public interests and were provided as a guard against frivolous and vexatious prosecutions... the said provision must be taken to be mandatory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows H.N. Rishbud precedent emphasizing peremptory language and policy to protect public servants; magistrate cannot surrender discretion but must satisfy himself on reasons for authorizing lower-rank officer.

holdings.text: It is desirable that magistrate's permission order under s.5A disclose reasons on its face, or prosecution prove aliunde that magistrate considered relevant circumstances if denied.

anchor.surface_text: it is desirable that the order giving the permission should ordinarily, on the face of it, disclose the reasons for giving the permission. For one reason or other, if the said salutary practice is not adopted... duty of the prosecution to establish...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles from Biswabhusan Naik on sanctions (desirable to set facts, prove aliunde if omitted); extended analogously to s.5A permissions; here neither done nor evidence adduced.

holdings.text: Investigation under s.5A started on January 11, 1955, prior to magistrate's permission on January 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: From the narration of facts given supra, it would be seen that in the present case Shri Bhalla gave information to the Sub-Inspector on January 11, 1955,... Under s. 5 of the Act, attempt to obtain... is an offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies CrPC s.4(1) definition of investigation (proceedings for evidence collection); facts show information received, trap laid, recoveries made, report sent on Jan 11 before permission.

precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 1 emphasised the necessity to adhere strictly to the provisions of s. 5A of the Act.

precedents.case_name: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: necessity to adhere strictly to the provisions of s. 5A of the Act; s. 5(4), proviso to s. 3 and s. 5A are mandatory
precedents.cited_holding: the said provision must be taken to be mandatory ... section 5(4) and proviso to section 3 of the Act and the corresponding section 5-A of Act LIX of 1952 are mandatory and not directory and that the investigation conducted in violation thereof bears the stamp of illegality.

precedents.citation: Biswabhusan Naik v. The State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court again considered the scope of s. 6 of the Act in Biswabhusan Naik v. The State of Orissa 1 . One of the questions raised there was that the sanction given by the Government was invalid.

precedents.case_name: Biswabhusan Naik v. The State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: sanction under Prevention of Corruption Act need not be in particular form or set out facts; omission not fatal if facts proved otherwise
precedents.cited_holding: It is not more necessary for the sanction under the Prevention of Corruption Act to be in any particular form, or in writing or for it to set out the facts in respect of which it is given than it was under clause 23 of the Order which their Lordships were considering. The desirability of such a course is obvious because when the facts are not set out in the sanction proof has to be given aliunde that sanction was given in respect of the facts constituting the offence charged, but an omission to do so is not fatal so long as the facts can be, and are provided in some other way.

precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh The State of Delhi 1
